case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Maharaja Pratapsingh Bahadur of Gidhaur

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 650 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 650 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment dated July 13, 1956, of the Pat

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment dated July 13, 1956, of the Patna High Court in Miscellaneous Judicial Case No. 665 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment dated July 13, 1956, of the Patna High Court in Miscellaneous Judicial Case No. 665 of 1954. Ganapathy Iyer and R. H. Dhebar, for the appellant. V. Viswanatha Sastri and R. C. Prasad, for the respondent. 1960. November 29.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on November 29, 1960 by HIDAYATULLAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. November 29. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-This is an appeal by the Commissioner of Income-tax with a certificate against the judgment and order of the High Court at Patna answering two questions of law referred to it under s. 66(1) of the Income-tax Act by the Tribunal, in the negative.

facts.text: Appeal by the Commissioner of Income-tax against Patna High Court judgment answering two questions negatively.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-This is an appeal by the Commissioner of Income-tax with a certificate against the judgment and order of the High Court at Patna answering two questions of law referred to it under s. 66(1) of the Income-tax Act by the Tribunal, in the negative. Those questions were Whether in the circumstances of the case assessment proceedings were validly initiated under s. 34 of the Indian Income-tax Act?

facts.text: Two questions referred by Tribunal to High Court under s.66(1): (1) Whether assessment proceedings validly initiated under s.34? (2) Whether interest on arrears of agricultural rent rightly included in assessee's income?

anchor.surface_text: Those questions were Whether in the circumstances of the case assessment proceedings were validly initiated under s. 34 of the Indian Income-tax Act? If so, whether in the circumstances of the case the amount received from interest on arrears of agricultural rent was rightly included in the income of the assessee ? The assessee, the Maharaja Pratapsingh Bahadur of Gidhaur, had agricultural income from his zamindari for the four assessment years 1944-45 to 1947-48.

facts.text: Assessee is the Maharaja Pratapsingh Bahadur of Gidhaur.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee, the Maharaja Pratapsingh Bahadur of Gidhaur, had agricultural income from his zamindari for the four assessment years 1944-45 to 1947-48. In assessing his income to income-tax, the authorities did number include in his assessable income interest received by him on arrears of rent.

facts.text: Assessee had agricultural income from his zamindari for assessment years 1944-45 to 1947-48.

anchor.surface_text: had agricultural income from his zamindari for the four assessment years 1944-45 to 1947-48. In assessing his income to income-tax, the authorities did number include in his assessable income interest received by him on arrears of rent. This was presumably so in view of the decision of the Patna High Court.

facts.text: In initial assessments, authorities did not include interest received on arrears of rent in assessee's assessable income.

anchor.surface_text: In assessing his income to income-tax, the authorities did number include in his assessable income interest received by him on arrears of rent. This was presumably so in view of the decision of the Patna High Court. When the Privy Council reversed the view of law taken by the Patna High Court in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Kamakhya Narayan Singh 1, the Income-tax Officer issued numberices under S. 34 of the 1 1948 16 I.T.R. 325.

facts.text: Privy Council reversed Patna High Court decision in CIT v. Kamakhya Narayan Singh [1948] 16 ITR 325.

anchor.surface_text: When the Privy Council reversed the view of law taken by the Patna High Court in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Kamakhya Narayan Singh 1 , the Income-tax Officer issued numberices under S. 34 of the 1 1948 16 I.T.R. 325. Indian Income-tax Act for assessing the escaped income. These numberices were issued on August 8, 1948.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer issued notices under s.34 for assessing escaped income on August 8, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: the Income-tax Officer issued numberices under S. 34 of the Indian Income-tax Act for assessing the escaped income. These numberices were issued on August 8, 1948. The assessments after the returns were filed, were companypleted on August 26, 1948.

facts.text: Assessments completed on August 26, 1948 after returns filed.

anchor.surface_text: These numberices were issued on August 8, 1948. The assessments after the returns were filed, were companypleted on August 26, 1948. Before the numberices were issued, the Income-tax Officer had number put the matter before the Commissioner for his approval, as the section then did number require it, and the assessments were companypleted on those numberices.

facts.text: Before issuing notices, Income-tax Officer did not put the matter before Commissioner for approval, as s.34 then did not require it.

anchor.surface_text: Before the numberices were issued, the Income-tax Officer had number put the matter before the Commissioner for his approval, as the section then did number require it, and the assessments were companyleted on those numberices. Section 34 was amended by the Income-tax and Business Profits Tax Amendment Act, 1948 No. 48 of 1948 , which received the assent of the Governor-General on Sep- tember 8, 1948.

facts.text: Section 34 amended by Income-tax and Business Profits Tax Amendment Act, 1948 (No. 48 of 1948), which received assent on September 8, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Section 34 was amended by the Income-tax and Business Profits Tax Amendment Act, 1948 No. 48 of 1948 , which received the assent of the Governor-General on Sep- tember 8, 1948. The appeals filed by the assessee were disposed of on September 14 and 15, 1951, by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, before whom numberquestion as regards the validity of the numberices under s. 34 was raised.

facts.text: Amending Act made sections 3 to 12 retrospective, deemed to have come into force on March 30, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The amending Act by its first section made ss. 3 to 12 of the amending Act retrospective by providing sections 3 to 12 shall be deemed to have companye into force on the 30th day of March, 1948 Section 8 of the amending Act substituted a new section in place of s. 34, and in addition to textual changes with which we are number companycerned, also added a proviso to the following effect Provided that- 1 the Income-tax Officer shall number issue a numberice under this sub-section unless he has recorded his reasons for doing so and the Commissioner is satisfied on such reasons that it is a fit case for the issue of such numberice.

facts.text: Assessee's appeals disposed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner on September 14 and 15, 1951; no question of validity of notices under s.34 raised.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals filed by the assessee were disposed of on September 14 and 15, 1951, by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, before whom numberquestion as regards the validity of the numberices under s. 34 was raised. The question of the validity of the numberices without the approval of the Commissioner appears to have been raised before the Tribunal for the first time.

facts.text: Validity of notices without Commissioner's approval raised for first time before Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The question of the validity of the numberices without the approval of the Commissioner appears to have been raised before the Tribunal for the first time. In that appeal, the Accountant Member and the Judicial Member differed, one holding that the numberices were invalid and the other, to the companytrary.

facts.text: Tribunal: Accountant Member and President held notices invalid; Judicial Member held valid; assessments set aside.

anchor.surface_text: In that appeal, the Accountant Member and the Judicial Member differed, one holding that the numberices were invalid and the other, to the companytrary. The President agreed with the Accountant Member that the numberices were invalid, and the assessments were ordered to be set aside. The Tribunal then stated a case and raised and referred the two questions, which have been quoted above.

facts.text: Tribunal stated case and referred two questions to Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal then stated a case and raised and referred the two questions, which have been quoted above. The High Court agreed with the companyclusions of the majority, and the present appeal has been filed on a certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Patna High Court agreed with Tribunal majority that notices invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court agreed with the companyclusions of the majority, and the present appeal has been filed on a certificate granted by the High Court. Section 34, as it stood prior to the amendment Act No. 48 of 1948, did number lay any duty upon the Income-tax Officer to seek the approval of the Commissioner before issuing a numberice under s. 34.

facts.text: Present appeal filed on certificate granted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: and the present appeal has been filed on a certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Prior to amendment, s.34 did not require ITO to seek Commissioner's approval before issuing notice.

anchor.surface_text: Section 34, as it stood prior to the amendment Act No. 48 of 1948, did number lay any duty upon the Income-tax Officer to seek the approval of the Commissioner before issuing a numberice under s. 34. The amending Act by its first section made ss. 3 to 12 of the amending Act retrospective by providing sections 3 to 12 shall be deemed to have companye into force on the 30th day of March, 1948.

facts.text: Amended s.34 added proviso requiring ITO to record reasons and obtain Commissioner's satisfaction before issuing notice.

anchor.surface_text: Section 8 of the amending Act substituted a new section in place of s. 34, and in addition to textual changes with which we are number companycerned, also added a proviso to the following effect Provided that- 1 the Income-tax Officer shall number issue a numberice under this sub-section unless he has recorded his reasons for doing so and the Commissioner is satisfied on such reasons that it is a fit case for the issue of such numberice.

facts.text: Notices issued on August 8, 1948, when statute deemed to require prior approval of Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: It is to be numbericed that the numberices were all issued on August 8, 1948, when on the statute book must be deemed to be existing an enactment enjoining a duty upon the Income- tax Officer to obtain prior approval of the Commissioner, and unless that approval was obstained, the numberices companyld number be issued The numberice were thus invalid.

facts.text: Court held notices invalid due to lack of Commissioner's approval under retrospective amendment.

anchor.surface_text: The numberice were thus invalid.

arguments.claim: Section 6 of the General Clauses Act saved the assessments as well as the notices

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner contends that s. 6 of the General Clauses Act, particularly cls. b and c saved the assessments as well as the notices. He relies upon a decision of the Privy Council in Lemm v. Mitchell 1 , Eyre v. Wynn-Mackenzie 2 and Butcher v. Henderson 3 in support of his proposition.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, under s. 6 of the General Clauses Act it is provided that where any Act repeals any enactment, then unless a different intention appears, the repeal shall not affect the previous operation of any enactment so repealed or anything duly done thereunder or affect any right, obligation or liability acquired, accrued or incurred under any enactment so repealed. ... thus by this retrospectivity, indicates a different intention which excludes the application of s. 6.

arguments.claim: Notices issued on August 8, 1948 were invalid as retrospective amendment required prior approval of Commissioner which was not obtained

anchor.surface_text: It is to be noticed that the notices were all issued on August 8, 1948, when on the statute book must be deemed to be existing an enactment enjoining a duty upon the Income- tax Officer to obtain prior approval of the Commissioner, and unless that approval was obtained, the notices could not be issued The notice were thus invalid.
The notice were thus invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notices issued on August 8, 1948, after retrospective date of March 30, 1948; proviso to s.34 required prior recording of reasons and Commissioner's satisfaction, which was not done.

holdings.text: by this retrospectivity, indicates a different intention which excludes the application of s. 6.

anchor.surface_text: The amending Act provides that the amending section shall be deemed to have come into force on March 30, 1948, and thus by this retrospectivity, indicates a different intention which excludes the application of s. 6. It is to be noticed that the notices were all issued on August 8, 1948, when on the statute book must be deemed to be existing an enactment enjoining a duty upon the Income- tax Officer to obtain prior approval of the Commissioner, and unless that approval was obtained, the notices could not be issued The notice were thus invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amending Act retrospectively deems ss.3-12 in force from March 30, 1948, going beyond mere repeal by substituting new s.34 with proviso, showing intention different from s.6 GCA savings clauses.

holdings.text: The Privy Council case is thus entirely different.

anchor.surface_text: The Privy Council case is thus entirely different. No doubt, under s. 6 of the General Clauses Act it is provided that where any Act repeals any enactment, then unless a different intention appears, the repeal shall not affect the previous operation of any enactment so repealed or anything duly done thereunder or affect any right, obligation or liability acquired, accrued or incurred under any enactment so repealed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: In Lemm v. Mitchell, prior action had concluded in defendant's favor with no appeal pending; revival did not allow new action exposing defendant to double jeopardy; facts differ from retrospective repeal affecting initiation of proceedings.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Kamakhya Narayan Singh  1

Indian Income-tax Act for assessing the escaped income. These numberices were issued on August 8, 1948. The assessments after the returns were filed, were companyleted on August 26, 1948.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Kamakhya Narayan Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: interest received on arrears of agricultural rent is not includible in assessable income

anchor.surface_text: Lemm v. Mitchell  1 , Eyre v. Wynn-Mackenzie  2  and Butcher v. Henderson  3  in support of his proposition. The last two cases have numberbearing upon this matter but strong reliance is placed upon the Privy Council case. In that case, the earlier, action which had been companymenced when the Ordinance had abrogated the right of action for criminal companyversation, had already ended in favour of the defendant and numberappeal therefrom was pending, and it was held that the revival of the right of action for criminal companyversation did number invest the plaintiff with a right to begin an action again and thus expose the defendant to a double jeopardy for the same act, unless the statute expressly and by definite words gave him that right.

precedents.cited_proposition: section 6 of the General Clauses Act saves previous operations, rights, liabilities, and legal proceedings under the repealed enactment
precedents.cited_holding: revival of a right of action does not allow a new action if prior proceedings ended without appeal pending, absent express statutory words

anchor.surface_text: , Eyre v. Wynn-Mackenzie  2  and Butcher v. Henderson  3  in support of his proposition. The last two cases have numberbearing upon this matter but strong reliance is placed upon the Privy Council case. In that case, the earlier, action which had been companymenced when the Ordinance had abrogated the right of action for criminal companyversation, had already ended in favour of the defendant and numberappeal therefrom was pending, and it was held that the revival of the right of action for criminal companyversation did number invest the plaintiff with a right to begin an action again and thus expose the defendant to a double jeopardy for the same act, unless the statute expressly and by definite words gave him that right. The Privy Council case is thus entirely different.

precedents.cited_proposition: section 6 of the General Clauses Act saves previous operations, rights, liabilities, and legal proceedings under the repealed enactment

anchor.surface_text: and Butcher v. Henderson  3  in support of his proposition. The last two cases have numberbearing upon this matter but strong reliance is placed upon the Privy Council case. In that case, the earlier, action which had been companymenced when the Ordinance had abrogated the right of action for criminal companyversation, had already ended in favour of the defendant and numberappeal therefrom was pending, and it was held that the revival of the right of action for criminal companyversation did number invest the plaintiff with a right to begin an action again and thus expose the defendant to a double jeopardy for the same act, unless the statute expressly and by definite words gave him that right. The Privy Council case is thus entirely different. No doubt, under s. 6 of the General Clauses Act it is provided that where any Act repeals any enactment, then unless a different intention appears, the repeal shall number affect the previous operation of any enactment so repealed or anything duly done thereunder or affect any right, obligation or liability acquired, accrued or incurred under any enactment so repealed.

anchor.surface_text: The amending Act provides that the amending section shall be deemed to have come into force on March 30, 1948, and thus by this retrospectivity, indicates a different intention which excludes the application of s. 6. It is to be noticed that the notices were all issued on August 8, 1948, when on the statute book must be deemed to be existing an enactment enjoining a duty upon the Income- tax Officer to obtain prior approval of the Commissioner, and unless that approval was obtained, the notices could not be issued The notice were thus invalid.
